Anyway, no - that build is missing. Unfortunenately, there is no 'browse' capability for product builds. The latest, however is 'buckminster.product-1.0.0.20060202.zip'.

That said, while playing around, you might as well use the regular buckminster install you get into your IDE. Assuming the regular 'update' process works normally, after you restart the IDE you should have a 'buckminster' executable alongside the eclipse executable. I.e. you get a headless environment there as well using the exact same code as in the 'product' packaging. Once you get everything working working you can tackle the product (and that one always requires customization to fit your needs). The main idea behind the 'product' is simply to enable a smaller package than the full IDE with all the paraphernalia it requires. But, if you'd rather start off with the product right now anyway, please holler and I'll show you how to get it set up.

Ah ok, I expected something exciting in it :)
But setting up a minimal product is still relevant to me as I need to compile against 3.1.2.

Sure - though using the product packaging wont truly help you with the issue of Eclipse 3.2 vs 3.1. The product comes bundled with a (minium) set of Eclipse 3.2 plugins anyway. The problem really belongs to a different space, namely of getting the rmap correct so that eclipse components will be materialized and/or bound into the workspace rather than falling back to 'plugins running in this instance'. You may also need to add cspex (cspec extension) files to your plugins where your dependencies on eclipse components is augmented to specify max version requirements (actually, I'm unsure if maybe that can be done directly on the plugin manifests nowadays). 

Anyway, if you're interested in the product packaging, see here: http://wiki.tada.se/display/buckminster/Buckminster+packaging, for an initial dump of packaging descriptions (it's a cut and paste job so the formatting is currently awful, I'll correct that when returning for restructuring that part...).
